Date and data-headings are corrected - SM
SD: Small correction in ref.
SD: Major correction in several Subents.
Subent 015, 016 deleted (in 015 value obtained from
data taking into account a relative yield of 0.6 % for
the heavier particles from another source; in 016
inverse value was given). Subent 018 deleted (inverse
value given in Subent 013). Subents 019-21 added.

bib_record.title: Energy distributions and absolute yields of the charged light particles emitted during the thermal neutron induced ternary fission of U-235

free_txt: 87 m curved neutron guide tube at
the high flux reactor of the Institute Laue-Langevin
The flux is 6.x 10**8 n/cm**2/sec, the Cd-data
is about 10.**6, the direct gamma flux from the
reactor is also reduced by a factor of about 10.**6.
Thermal Maxwellian neutron spectrum from HFR.
Identification of the charged particles with
E-DE (telescope) detectors.
Pulse height discrimination
Data from Nucl.Phys.,A346(1980)461 and thesis.
.    This value was obtained using the true LRA-yield,
i.e. From the integration of a non Gaussian energy
distribution.
.    This value was obtained using an extrapolated
incorrect LRA-yield, from the integration of an
extrapolated Gaussian energy distribution.
The energy distribution of the protons was Gaussian.
The true LRA yield value includes the non Gaussian
alpha particles, probably produced in the
decays of He-6 and He-5.
A fully depleted dE-detector
with a thickness of 95.6 microns, an active area of
200 mm**2 and an energy resolution of better than
25 keV for 5.5 MeV alphas. The dE-detector was covered
with a 20 microns thick Al-foil to stop the alpha
particles from spontaneous decay and the binary
fragments. The E-detector had a thickness of 1500
microns and an energy resolution of 23 keV.
Statistical errors only.
A 199 micro-grams/cm**2 thick U-F(4) layer evaporated
onto a gold foil backing of 2 microns thickness. Its
isotopic enrichment was 99.524%. This sample was an
optimum one for the reduction of the background
from (alpha,p) and (n,p) reactions.
Table 1 from Nucl.Phys.,A346(1980)461

The true LRA yield value includes the non Gaussian

A 26.7 microns thick dE-detector
(active area 300 mm**2, energy resolution about
35 keV) and a 500 microns thick E-detector (active
area 450 mm**2, energy resolution 40 keV). This
detector assembly was shielded with a 20 microns
thick aluminium foil against binary fragments and
spontaneous decay alphas.
An unshielded telescope,
dE-Detector of 33.9 microns,
E-detector 500 microns thick.
Statistical errors only.

aluminium backing.

Since the ternary alpha-particles were detected between
6.1 MeV and 28.1 MeV, the measured integrated yield was
corrected for the parts of the spectrum above 28.1 MeV
(0.1 %) and between 0. and 6.1 MeV, which corresponds
only to a small fraction of the total yield. This
fraction was calculated based on the results for the
235U(n'th,f) ternary alpha-distribution, which resulted
in a correction of + (3.7 +- 1)%.
Totally depleted 26.7 microns thick detector.
No information about source of uncertainties
A 3.6 micro-grams/cm2 U-F(4) layer on a 10. microns
thick aluminium backing.
